docs.lead_paragraph: IN the recent Hollywood issue of Vanity Fair, 15-year-old Hilary Duff was aptly named ''The Tween Queen'' for her virtual domination and definition of cool for kids in the ''in-between'' years -- those roughly 9-to-13-year-olds with major purchasing power who are too grown up for cartoons but not quite ready for ''Gilmore Girls.'' As the star of the Disney Channel series ''Lizzie McGuire'' (also on ABC on Saturday mornings), Ms. Duff has found herself at the helm of a burgeoning franchise that includes record contracts, a clothing line, home accessories, dolls and a successful line of books. She's about to star in ''The Lizzie McGuire Movie'' (opening Friday), and she's just enjoyed a bit of Hollywood fame in the hit kiddie-spy flick ''Agent Cody Banks.'' All this said, it is tempting to dismiss Ms. Duff as too annoyingly cute, too annoyingly blond, too annoyingly young -- and just too annoyingly everywhere. That is, if you haven't seen her in action.
docs.abstract: Hillary Frey commentconsiders popularity among 9-to-13 year-olds of Hilary Duff, star of Lizzie McGuire television series on Disney Channel and ABC; admits to being fan of program with plausible scripts and star role model who is happy to be teenager and in no rush to grow up; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Men are seldom kind about women playing team sports. If you've ever overheard a group of them sitting in front of a big-screen TV when an ad for the W.N.B.A. comes on, it isn't pretty. But mention that a group of women in the Deep South (where every man, woman and child follows the game with Pentecostal intensity) has started a league to play professional tackle football, and you get a different reaction entirely, one of mute astonishment -- followed by slow, serious nods and mutterings of ''Now, I'd like to see that.'' Truth is, a fully suited female defensive tackle gets as much silent male respect as the 5-foot-2 housewife alighting from the driver's seat of a Dodge Ram 3500 Cummins Turbo Diesel in a supermarket parking lot. Some things are such powerful evidence of guts that they negate even gender. Tackle football is one of them. Last weekend two teams of 40 to 45 players met in the preseason opener between the Nashville Dream and the Alabama Renegades. By the time their first 10-game regular season starts in March there will be 10 more teams. Catherine Masters, founder of the National Women's Football League and owner of the Nashville Dream, estimates that 80 percent of the calls from individuals interested in shelling out the $35,000 to buy a start-up team came from women. ''In three years, we could have enough revenue to sign Marion Jones, if we play it right,'' says Masters. But for now, the players happily pocket $125 per game and call themselves pro athletes. Unlike their N.F.L. counterparts, these women of the N.W.F.L. are grown-ups, with lives and children and real jobs, as therapists, farmers, engineers and rocket scientists. Some played soccer and rugby and the like in college; others simply grew up with big brothers thumping on them day in and day out. Most of the players are blunt about what drew them to tryouts: ''The hitting.'' ''I wanted to hit people.'' ''It was the running and the hitting.''
docs.abstract: Photo essay on National Women's Football League, founded by Catherine Masters; full-contact tackle football league has just played preseason opener (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME bargain hunters see government auctions as a way to save a bundle on cars, furniture, diamonds and flat-screen televisions. For informed buyers, bidding may yield good investments. But the bang of the gavel can hold risk for novices. Sponsored by federal, state and local agencies selling seized property, hundreds of auctions are held around the country each year. Depending on the sale, bidding may be done online, by phone or in person. The merchandise is an eclectic mix -- from big-ticket items like homes, cars and trucks to products like Rolex watches and Bose speakers. There may also be cartons of air-conditioners, pottery, clothing and shampoo -- and even slabs of granite and machine parts.

headline.main: At These Sales, You May Find the Kitchen Sink

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the manager of an indie-rock band fronted by an accordion player, Camille Acey, 23, is used to uphill battles. So when Ms. Acey and the band, Movers and Shakers, decided to build a ''rock garden'' on the roof of a loft building in Long Island City, Queens, they solved the obvious problem with 175 pounds of neutral-tone buttons from a company that donates surplus materials to artists. Ms. Acey was a contestant in a ''gardening challenge'' sponsored by ReadyMade, a Berkeley-based do-it-yourself magazine for those who are young, hip and inclined to turn their soda empties into camp stoves. The participants, chosen by the editors, had to remake a 100-square-foot space, relying on found objects and the landscape's existing features, all within a $200 budget provided by the magazine.
docs.abstract: Camille Acey and her indie-rock band Movers and Shakers create 'rock garden' on roof of loft building in Long Island City, New York City, substituting 175 pounds of buttons for rocks; photos; gardening challenge is sponsored by ReadyMade, Berkeley-based do-it-yourself magazine for those who are young, hip and inclined toward recycling environmentalism (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a hot, dry day last month, on a cul-de-sac in a subdivision in Denver, a clue barely visible to the untrained eye led Jack Rooks to stop his compact Toyota pickup in front of a two-story clapboard house. He examined the evidence and knocked on the door. A dark-haired woman opened it a crack, peering out into the sunlight. ''Y'all are hosing down the area out here,'' Mr. Rooks said, pointing to a length of rubber snaking from the open garage onto the bluegrass lawn. A tiny trickle of water ran into the gutter and down the street. ''You're not supposed to be doing that.'' He issued a warning and got back in his truck.
docs.abstract: Some Denver, Colo, residents have given up lawns for either artificial turf or creative gardens in wake of stringent watering rules put in place due to severe drought; city is trying to set example by filling planters with more drought-tolerant plants, move expected to cut water consumption by 30 percent; other strategies for landscaping in arid climate noted; photos (M)
